div1.p: Kissinger relates his story and political difficulties in obtaining financial support.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Kissinger to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 18, 1926
div1.p:
Your: Very, welcome
letter was received.

I, canot begin to tell you
how pleased Mr. Kissinger was
to hear from you,
he is not able to write
only. a very little so I have
to do his coresponding for
him he is feeling real
poorly at present.

has a cold and act to
me like the flue.

We are very glad Indeed.
That Prof: Peabody gave you
our adress.

We feel that he is a
very good friend and.
spending lots of his
very valueble time in
our behalf.

Mr. Kissinger has always
been an admirer of
Major Reed and had
felt had he lived things
would have been very
different- Than they are
we have had some very
nice letters from Dr. Agramonte
of Cuba. The only one that
is living of. the yellow
fever board.

he has offered any
service or Influence
he might have in our behalf,
you say you have had.
to bear the Indifrence.
of Congress. It Seems' to bad
and great pity that Congress
cannot see or seem to
realize what these men
have given
No not for one moment
does Mr. Kissinger regret
that he had the privalage
of Voluntering himself. To
Major Reed for the experiment
but re Joieces in his own
heart that he had a little
part in helping. Medical
Science and Humanity
but does regret that his
health is such that he
has to depend on the governed
and friends for our
suport, for he has felt
at times as though he
had lost his Citizenship
because he dare not
express his opinion in
regards to some acts of,
the Gavment.
or for what he regards
as right such. as upholding
the Lazear Law, he fought
against that Demon of Liymana
and the friends of It said
they would cause him, Trouble
and It seems' as if the
ones' in Washington was only
to glad to listen to them-
and placed him under
Humiliation,

Mr. Kissinger heard last
eve that one of the Boys that
was in the expemet had just
died- in Chicago but did
not find out which one,
we, are having a real.
cold spell and snow. storm
but have had very nice
weather.

now dear Mrs Reed we,
were both very glad to hear
from you and hope we may
have another letter, from you
this letter seems' to me, mixed
up but Its rather hard
to write for some one else
so hope you excuse. all the
mistakes.

Mr. Kissinger joins me
in Kinds regards and
best wishes.

closer.signed:
Mrs. John R.Kissinger
John R Kissinger
